Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: International Constraints and Informal Trade Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The term informal (or grey) economy refers to businesses, economic activities, and workers that are not government regulated and are not captured in measures of national GDP or GNP. Even so, the informal economy is known to comprise a significant part of world economic activity: the International Labor Organization estimates that globally, it employs over half of the world's labor force. The research supported by this award takes a multidimensional approach to the question of how informality plays out in an increasingly globalized economic environment. The focus is on the nexus of three inter-related dynamics: vernacular economic practices, state surveillance, and the effects of global forces. The research is important because informal economic activities are increasingly felt beyond the local level and can produce significant unintended effects on the outcomes of international economic regulatory policies and practices.

The research will be conducted by State University of New York, Binghamton, anthropology doctoral student, Ehsan Lor Afshar, with the oversight of Dr. Thomas M. Wilson. The researcher will engage in research in a region divided by the international borders that have been central to major informal cross-border trade networks. Examining how these networks interact with global regulation, such as the international framework for Anti Money Laundering and Counter Financing Terrorism and regional economic sanctions, will provide a revealing case study of the potentials for such programs and policies to be efficacious, reconfigured, or transformed at the local level. The researcher will collect data through a mix of anthropological methods: (1) participant observation in a major wholesale market's everyday life, with a focus on three divergent types of merchandise (foodstuffs, cloth goods, and electronics); (2) surveys of a merchant sample; (3) semi-structured interviews with merchant association leaders, other NGOs, government officials, and a sub-sample of merchants; (4) focus groups of merchants and community leaders; and (5) archival research. The research will advance social scientific understanding of how global financial regulations and sanctions interact with local unregulated or semi-regulated economic practices. Research findings will be helpful for state officials and global organizations by clarifying the picture of the effects of transnational policies on the ground.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the unintended consequences of economic sanctions on Iran has been the creation of new forms of illegality within the country’s economy and across its borders. Drawing on more than eight months of fieldwork, between December 2018 and July 2019 in Iran’s Baluchistan, this project explores how economic sanctions on Iran are perceived, experienced, and responded to by local communities across Iran’s eastern borders. The focus is on the practical consequences of severe currency devaluation, instigated by economic sanctions, as well as the coping strategies, deployed by local people, to curtail their effects.

The fieldwork was conducted at three locations in Iran’s Baluchistan, including Zahedan, Mir-Javeh, and Jiroft. The investigators were more interested in the intersection of economic sanctions with local and informal economy. The main objective was to understand how severe devaluation of Iran’s currency, Rial, triggered by financial sanctions, has contributed to the surge of informal economy of the region. In May 2018, the US government withdrew from the Joint Comprehensive Plan Of Action (JCPOA), reimposing a wide range of sanctions on Iran’s economic and financial sectors. This move trembled Iran’s economy resulting in an economic contraction of about 8 percent, an inflation rate of over 60 percent in domestic goods, and more importantly a sharp drop in the value of rial against US dollar by losing about 80 percent of its worth in a few months.

In Zahedan, this project makes inquires about the impact of currency devaluation on monetary transactions and business contracts in Rasooli Bazaar. As the Baluch’s largest commercial hub, Rasooli Bazaar is where a large quantity of illegally imported commodities, ranging from foodstuffs and clothing to electronics and household appliances, is openly and freely exchanged every day. For decades, Baluch merchants of Rasooli Bazaar have developed their extensive commercial networks in Iran and Pakistan. Since 2012, the exchange rate of Pakistani Rupee has increased by %11000, jumping from 90 rials to 1000 rials. This sharp increase in the value of rupee has had two important consequences. First it has made the imported goods from Pakistan very expensive. Second it has terminated various debt-credit relations between traders and their suppliers and customers, as the wild and unpredictable currency devaluation prevents any long-term relation to form. Our project, specifically, portrays tactics and strategies adopted by the Bazaar’s traders who ought to deal with an increasingly devalued currency.

In Mir-Javeh, located at the border of Iran and Pakistan, this study explores how sanctions encourage illegal activities by both local officials and people. The border marketplace in Mir-Javeh used to be a place of imported crops and goods from Pakistan. Due to devaluation of Iran’s currency, the marketplace was shut down for several years and many people lost their source of income. Since March 2019, Iran’s government has temporarily suspended the ban on exporting crops and foodstuff. As a result, the flow of the same group of commodities at Mir-Javeh’s border marketplace has been reversed as the fall in value of rial makes the Iranian products much cheaper compared to their Pakistani rivals. By excluding this particular marketplace from the state surveillance in terms of taxation and customs control, for political considerations though, parts of local government participate in the illegalization of the market. Here, the main argument is economic sanctions and currency devaluation propel the social actors to the ways in which the scope of informality is inevitably expanded.

In Jiroft, the project investigates the revival of an old association of financial mutuality in the region, called Bazl. In the reinvented Bazl system, people, frustrated with the sanctioned and dysfunctional banks, club together with acquaintances and even strangers to pool their cash, transferring it to each member as gifts, with the expectation of reciprocation in future. The total amount of cash, circulated in Bazl in Jiroft, is estimated at 15000 billion rilas ($ 140 million) yearly, which is quite larger than total amount of loans dispensed by banks and other financial institutions. Given formal banks’ predicaments, choosing Bazl as a means of storing value for future, appears to be an act of rational choice. Bazl, in Jiroft, carries out several functions: it produces and facilitates lasting social relationships, assists in maintaining social order through generating hope and solidarity, and serves as an insurance, investing instrument and store of value. However, it also provides a realm for the money, earned through criminal activities, to be washed in a legitimate cultural scheme. Here, our findings depict a condition under which the misery brought about by currency devaluation drive people to exhaust local cultural resources.
